Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Investigating the Social and Technological Implications of Mass-Capture Fishing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Archaeological research provides a unique, long-term perspective on the dynamics among society, culture, technology and environment. Accordingly, archaeological studies of maritime adaptations have traditionally focused on long-term processes, broadening understanding of general trends such as resource depletion, often glossing over the consequences of specific events. This study focuses on a particular case of social and economic reorganization in order to illuminate the impact of innovation during times of punctuated social and political change. Just as industrialization has had a huge impact on fishing operations, fishing communities and fisheries populations in recent times, changes in fishing technology and resource use among pre-capitalist societies were closely tied to social, political, and economic reorganization. This project presents a rare opportunity to connect archaeological data that stretches back millennia to historical and modern day fisheries data in order to better understand the factors that promote continuity and the forces that generate abrupt and lasting change. The results of this research will be shared globally, and will provide a deep-time perspective on fishery sustainability. Student participants in this research will receive training and experience in archaeological laboratory methods, faunal analysis and specimen curation.

University of Florida doctoral student Ginessa Mahar, supervised by Dr. Neill Wallis, will investigate how changing social, political, and economic circumstances among coastal fisher-hunter-gatherer societies affected subsistence practices and technological innovation. During the Woodland era of the Southeastern USA, the appearance of complex civic-ceremonial centers indicates political, economic, and social reorganization on the part of formerly small-scale dispersed societies. Such developments likely required a complete reorganization of subsistence practices to facilitate these unprecedented large gatherings. This study investigates the traditional fishing practices of Early Woodland (500 B.C. - A.D. 200) coastal communities along the northern Gulf Coast of Florida and how they were affected by the intensification of ritual practices after A.D. 200, when complex civic-ceremonial centers were constructed and inhabited. Specifically, this study asks if traditional fishing protocols were expanded to facilitate such gatherings as well as daily consumption at civic-ceremonial centers, or if innovative practices were developed and executed. Archaeological samples will be analyzed from multiple sites that date prior to, during, and after the onset of these centers. Fish bones from these archaeological contexts will be used to assess the type and scale of technology used to facilitate the changing needs of these coastal communities. Fish size is critical to the assessment of resource acquisition, timing, and resource sustainability, thus allometric formulae will be generated using modern specimens from the Gulf of Mexico provided by the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. This project also incorporates the results of previously conducted research including ethnographic fieldwork, experimental fish capture, and archaeological material culture analysis. The data generated by this project will benefit not only archaeological studies within the region but also multi-disciplinary, long-term fisheries projects worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding from the National Science Foundation supported dissertation research by Ginessa Mahar to investigate the interconnections between subsistence technology and transformations in social, economic, and political organization among small-scale coastal fisher-hunter-gatherers. The project focused on an area of the Northern Gulf coast of Florida known as the Lower Suwannee region during the Middle Woodland Period.

The Woodland Period (ca. 1000 B.C. – A.D. 1000) of southeastern North America is characterized by marked changes in political and social organization on a grand scale. The appearance of large civic-ceremonial centers, comprised of open plazas, platform and burial mounds, and expansive village middens, marked heightened levels of social gathering and interaction among Middle and Late (ca. A.D. 400 – 1000) Woodland Period groups. Artifacts recovered from such sites suggest participation in extra-local religious movements, while the construction of civic-ceremonial centers drew in dispersed populations from near and far. This period is also known for significant technological innovations including agriculture and the bow and arrow, and as this project suggests, the development of fishing infrastructure.

Shell Mound (8LV42) is a coastal civic-ceremonial center in the Lower Suwannee region of the North Florida Gulf coast. Comprised of mostly oyster shell, the mound measures 180 m in plan and over 7 m in height and surrounds a large central plaza. The mortuary facility associated with Shell Mound is perhaps one of the most intensively utilized and most elaborately furnished of those on the Gulf coast, attesting to the level of religious and cultural significance of the site. Beyond ritual intensification, the site also contains evidence for economic intensification in what might be the earliest evidence for oyster mariculture in the region. Furthermore, 2 km to the south of Shell Mound is what has been recently identified as a fish trap facility, a tidally operated series of interconnected pools enclosed by a seawall of emplaced oyster shell.

This project was developed to identify the fishing methods employed by communities both prior to and during the apogee of Shell Mound (ca. A.D. 400 – 650) with the aim of understanding how fishing practices are related to social, economic, and political transformations in historical context. Specifically, this research addresses the following questions: were traditional fishing practices expanded to accommodate the rise of civic-ceremonial centers during the Middle Woodland period? Or were novel technologies developed to facilitate the large gatherings and increased labor demand?

NSF funding supported zooarchaeological identification of faunal remains from 20 archaeological contexts from 6 sites within the Lower Suwannee region as well as radiocarbon assays that were used to further refine the regional chronology. In addition to zooarchaeological identification, allometric methods were used to infer fish size from measured skeletal elements. For this phase of the project, over 30 new allometric equations were developed for the 12 most ubiquitous fishes identified in the selected contexts.

The findings of this investigation were substantial. Contexts dating to the CCC era showed a strong pattern of mass-capture fishing (e.g. seine netting) while earlier contexts displayed characteristics of individual capture (e.g. spearing). These inferences are based on fish capture models generated from an earlier portion of this study that involved both ethnographic and experimental methods as well as data provided from the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. Whereas the early contexts contained large, reef-oriented, non-schooling species, later contexts contained smaller, bottom-oriented, schooling species. Furthermore, this study also revealed that fishing practices varied during the CCC era. Ceremonial pit contexts, deposited in the summer, displayed characteristics unlike daily refuse deposits and could not be explained by the seine netting model generated for this study. Mullet (Mugil sp.) dominate the ceremonial pit contexts, and this study suggests that the fish trap facility may have been employed to supply fishes for the summer ceremonial feasts at Shell Mound. Thus as more people gathered and labor was concentrated on ritual activities and public works, fishing practices shifted to capture more fish per unit effort (from spearing to seine netting). Furthermore, fishing infrastructure was constructed to provide fishes (mullet and others) for summer feasts, suggesting that fishing technology is inherently connected to larger social, economic and political circumstances of small-scale coastal fisher-hunter-gatherers.

The results of this research will aid anthropological studies that seek to understand why and how small-scale communities develop, augment, and intensify practices to provision both daily needs and periodic events. Furthermore, archaeologists wishing to incorporate allometric studies into their research will benefit from the equations created for this research and modern fisheries biologists may benefit from the data generated on a nearly 2,000 year old fishery. Finally, this project has provided educational opportunities for students and community volunteers alike. Collaboration with fisherfolk in the study region provided information and experiences critical for the development of this project while fostering a deeper appreciation of the cultural heritage of the Gulf coast.
